content:

The second topic is around Sepolia Testnet, faucets and validators. I was speaking with <@397809066115727383> on the topic and he suggested, my best bet is to reach out to client teams. I don't want to tag all the teams in this post, but if anyone could help me bring this to their awareness I would really appreciate it. We have a faucet set up already to provide ETH and need to develop a sustainable solution to keep providing ETH to developers (currently ~210,000 requests funded). <@543900561460822016> was super generous and provided us with a large amount recently. But we expect to run out later this year and would like to work with teams to come up with a beneficial arrangement for all!

author: jgm
content: Regarding the second item, do you have any idea of the amount of ETH you require, preferably in terms of amount per month?

author: parithosh
content:
1) Napkin math: You could get away with 5-10k validators per 4 core/16gb/150gb ssd machine(only really fine on testnets and to keep costs lower). This should be roughly 100-150$/mo on some cheaper cloud providers. Alternatively you can buy 1 NUC at a standalone cost of ~500-1k if you have the bandwidth and location for it(definitely the cost effective option if you have the expertise for it). You'd need 15-20 of these for good measure to manage 100k keys. Its currently pure altruism, there's no incentive to run validators. For most teams, its a way to test at scale. Often client teams will deploy alpha versions on testnets to gather data before a more public beta. Similar goes for staking providers and dvts. Additionally, the testnet will undergo upgrades before mainnet, so its an easy way to know directly if your client/product/etc might face issues during the mainnet upgrade. If the cost/validator count is not something that makes sense for your setup, you can always run fewer validators and still help keep the testnet up and running.
